bibl.title: Newspaper clipping, The Havana Post, June 26, 1900

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Havana Post, June 26, 1900
div1.p:
A Cafe Proprietor in Camp Detention Says
He Is Not Fed.

THE POST has received the following
short but positive note:

“DEAR SIR: Publish this. please. We
are here one mile from Quemados de Ma-
riauao, with nothing to eat and water
[unclear]
business.

The writer is one of the thirty who
have been moved from Quemados by an
order which prohibits any non-immune
from living within the limits of the
town.

A reporter of THE POST was at this
same camp on Sunday with Dr. Stark.
While it is true that the men and women
are compelled to live in tents, it is also
true that the tents have been well fitted
up. As to food, those detained there
are being fed from the best stores which
the commissary affords, if the words of
Dr. Stark or the chief of the commisary
are to be depended upon. As to water,
it is hauled to them twice each day.

When the reporter and Dr. Stark were
at the camp on Sunday, Dr. Stark asked
if the inmates were in need of anything
and received a negative reply. The
camp looks pleasant, though it doubt-
less is a hardship to keep the men away
from business, no matter what the char-
acter of the business may be.
